comment: This is the worst game ever created it shouldn't event be in the top 10,000

A fairly standard worker placement game, perhaps for its time it was good but now this doesn't cut it, low interaction and none of the tension of Agricola. Re-theme whilst interesting doesn't go far enough. I would have gone for everything underground (lichen/mushrooms/weird chemical vents, monster farming etc) not more meadows and sown fields. And playing at 7p is...zzzzzz.

There are better tile placement games. There are better worker placement games. Too many things to read. No interactiona between players. Can't see the fun in it. I guess overhyped by the named of Rosenberg and review by Dice Tower. If I get this for free, I will sell it immediately. JASE Just another Soulless Euro
《农场主》都玩不明白的我自取其辱。
too old
Not as good as Agricola. Multi-player solitaire. Played 10 times.

A POS, overly hyped by Dice Tower. Egyptian and Mediterranean themes seems to drives them crazy but not just a rehash of the same old crap, over and over.

The number of players on the box, one and two players give me a break, at one player, this is like playing chess with yourself, at two be very prepared to play the exactly same game again, what it really means there will be another edition coming out that’s really a two player game, if it follows past patterns from this so called game designer.

Man, somebody’s guys turn into one trick pony’s after while. This is a sad trend in the board game industry.

With two major "wild card" mechanisms, all the open information in the game, and almost 100% static set up game, this is a very boring activity.

A game with zero tension and just a solitary point big salad summary game.

In a nutshell.

Why do people like the possibility to play the same game over and over and over as any randomness in the tiles which replaced the cards are totally gone, take the standard Agricola game, don’t even bother to shuffle the deck, flip all the cards over, first come first pick,, you now have Caverna.

It defies the very definition of board game.

I came here, because of all the people rating mature themed games like KD:M or Hate with a 1, just because of their mature them.
This games theme is boring!

Man, I loathe this game. It is right up there with Monopoly.

Why do people dislike this thing but rate it N/A? T even gets a 7 for those people who dislike it. Look at the comments. Gee, post a rating to unskew the ratings.

I made the mistake of buying this and then playing another copy and realizing the mistake.

This is from a reviewer about another game but it sums up this yet again rehash from this phone it in designer, "....epitome of inelegant, kitchen-sink designs that leave me feeling cold after hours of slogging through what feels like a meaningless point salad of mismatched mechanisms.

The worst is getting sucker in by reviews and the hype.

One of the most expensive regret buys I have ever made. Despite the publisher's price fixing in the U.S., artificial pricing, this thing is a nightmare to unload and try to recoup your cost.

It is a niche buy. Those that wanted it, payed up, those that didn't, don't want it, what is left are those that expect to get a mint unplayed copy for $45, shipped, I kid you not. Back out after back out when they discovered the $18.00 shipping on this cinder block.

This behavior of publishing a game that "is not for everybody ", Mayfair words, posted here, in terms of that $98.99 manufactured price, not only causes it to be hard to sell, but also skews BGG's rating.

It is like that Magic card collecting, Dice Masters. These people willing to spent a fortune on it, will vote their life style high up, not so much say for a game like Airlines Europe which who get a mixture of buyers aka a better sample of buyers, and a more balanced rating.

Running a poll on 100K Lamborghini buyers on how they like their car is a moot point. They were in love with the designer, the car before going in, before the purchase.

Interestingly, same group that just loves this game are the ones that wanted an expansion to it 1 month after owning. What the hell is that all about? You read,"well if it had this or that", "I sure wished it had", to add some variation, yet 10 rating from these people. Read some of the glow job comments, I have never seen a game so loved by a group and yet that same group want so many changes to. A game that cost 2 cents less then $100.00 should have longer legs, not need expansions.

Look at the N/A comments rating, amazing so many dislike this thing but fail to give it a rating so it would reflect the real rating. What is wrong with these people?

Thoughts and just bad vibes after playing this, factoring the money for it:

I'm done watching Dice Tower reviews they are just too skewed to personal "like" of the reviewer, I'm done with this designer. There is a feeling of cranking out the reviews, there is a strong feeling on a one game played review, to keep up with the status quote. A problem I guess when this is now part of your income? I prefer more of a hobbies review.

I don't have the luxury of getting free games to review nor do we have those wax poetic FLGS to try before you buy. Our shops are more of the Comic Book Guy. So, I need a better review, with some real insight in the game.

I really wonder how often this thing hits the table. To me it's a groaner, "do we have to play that".

An amazingly dull, flat, repetitive game. There is no direction in this game. This is just a church groups activity, it is no game.

The real deal is you don't seem to be playing against other players, only yourself and trying to beat your easily obtained score by 1-2 points. Seems to be totally missed by any review of this thing. The lack of any real randomization just added to this besting your last score.

As for Dice a Towers over blown love for this thing, why is it Egyptian themes, Mediterranean trading themes get no love, only because you have played more games and thrown them away then most people will ever own; you never grow tired of just another rethemed, get this or that, no real reason, now trade those in, that is all it is to it resource management; and yet again with this guy, this so called game; a piss poor, erroneous in real play, player count on the box; or you never tire of yet another small variant of Yahtzee game with another theme slapped on?

I can't wait for the fixed priced $50, 2 player game only Caverna, if history repeats itself, created by pulling out some boring mechanism out of this penny a point salad from McDonald's $1.00 menu. The worst Euro cube pusher has nothing over Caverna's mindless, directionless game play.

Totally amazing Dice Tower's loathing of Feld's games but the way over the top of this ilk of games especially from this designer. It is like buying the same puzzle with a different theme for $100.

To Dice Tower, I'd rather play Shadow Era over Caverna. I would like to say I would like my $100 plus back, but I can't, sold for $65 dollars plus 2 $15 mini expansions, one for Caverna, one for another game just go get rid of it.

Yes, quite a lost. I figured I got $35.00 for it. You best know you want this thing given Mayfair Games business model of price flooring and slapping on any MSRP price they think they are entitled to.

I finally realize with this game Dice Tower reviews are basically infomercial and are nothing more.

Classic Rosenberg, another phone it in game.

Wow, another Tom Vasel over hype. Yet another farm game, worst, get x, get y, trade it in. How this qualifies as a game is beyond me, having and almost 100 percent open information game, having all the tiles available on a first come first serve is a boring, stagnant boring waste of time. The price is ridiculous for what you get out of it. Played once and sold. A very badly valued game.
Fragoso

$112 plus tax? Is this a joke? Of course it is. Gets a 1 for price alone. Gets another 1 for being yet another farming game. Gets another 1 for set up time. Rosenberg needs to get his head out of the manure and go to the beach for vacation. The man knows how to beat a dead cow.

Uwe Rosenberg at his best it would seem, unfortunately.

I'm not sure what this is. There is just no enjoyable game here, just a lot of pretty parts.

They claim Euros can feel like cube pushers. What do you call the collection of games Uwe Rosenberg cranks out that are just mindless resource collecting then converting them into something else, just slapping on another theme?

Another mindless, amazingly directionless, slow, slow point race, that fanboys like to call a sandbox. More like playing in a cat litter box.

Worst game I have ever played, too many wild card options, just multi player solitude, especially felt below 4 players, over 5 a boring downtime, I'm not sure what it is.

Get a score, try next time to bump it by 1-2 points by trying something slightly different. You can pretty much play the same game over and over.

That 1 raving review for this thing is the only reason I can find figure out why it is rated so high as people align themselves to that reviewer.

Get pass the over chrome there is nothing here. This is just the same old crap seen in a series of games from this designer, bet we will see a watered down version, some small mechanism pulled, sold as a 2 player game, with a price tag of $60.00 if history repeats itself.

I question just how often it gets to the table and that it supports anything but 4 player games.

If I could give it a zero and it would mean something I would. Way over priced and over chromed especially adding in 5-7 players. This must have just been done to justify that price. Watching 6 other players AP over upturned tiles, then getting blocked only to be able to easily work around it is a snooze feast. I'm not sure why feeding was added to the game given how easy it is, just a minor nuisance in the game.

I wished I could give this a zero.

Prime example of Tom Vasel over hyping a game, the parts, the box, gets him going, then throw in another Rosenberg rehash we have seen time and time again from him, that Vasel can not get enough and you get a very skeptical review wrapped around high praise. I understand this is a personal perspective, preference, but Vasel has issues to themes he has gotten tired of, therefore in his world "we" should too", but he never seems to grow tired of this resource trade in game with just another theme slap on. As long as it is stepped, get a, get b, trade a and B, it is another slam dunk as it is themed and make sense?

Be warned, the high rating of this game maybe caused by the Rosenberg Fan Club, those that will shell out a $100, don't care about Mayfair's forced getting near MSRP. Those that want it, in the Rosenberg fan club and willingness to pay that artificial high price are very unlikely to rate it low. They go into loving it. Anybody stating there is tension in this game must be playing some other game. It is totally lacking in that regard.

Learn a valuable lesson about watching Dice Towers. Well, I have stopped watching it, defaulting to others. I can not take the dice love, the Rosenberg worship, the whining I have played thousands of games and I am sick of, Egyptian themes, Mediterranean themes, etc. Well, I haven't.
Good luck selling your used copy. Very niche market.
Bad, bad as it gets. Just another rehash this guy is known for. How much of this resource collection, trade it in for something else, with no rhyme or reason for any action.
Static setup lowered replayability.
boring, ugly piece of crap !

This game is like taking a 5,000 piece puzzle, placing all the pieces face up, round robin picking up one piece. Where each person works on his own section in front of him, like a private mat, the rule being each piece has to fit in with one of his previous pieces.

This was one waste of money. The artificial high price by MayFairGames and the imposed restrictions forced on resellers not to offer discounts beyond a token amount you have to think hard about buying this game.

Like most of this guy's designs his player count is way off.
5 players is a drag, I can not fathom anyone playing 6 or 7.

Interestingly you don't hear from the fanboy's reviews anything about this point.

The price of this game could have been greatly reduced if the player count had been adjusts 3-4. Solo play seems pointless.

For $98.89 plus shipping this was the biggest mistake I have ever made.

I will avoid both Rosenberg and Outlook/MayFairGames in the future. I don't care for MayFairGames interference with supply and demand.

The fantasy setting appears like a Fata Morgana, shimmering with adventure and cozy cuteness, as players step deeper and deeper into the dry wilderness of accountancy.

Like a bazillion of similar games this one could be played on an Excel sheet, where one manages resources and calculates the return of selected actions.

In contrast to the bazillion of similar games, Caverna is tailored for the more experienced accountant (speaking of stereotypes), because it's front-loaded with more actions, has no tension, no interpersonal component and a staggering amount of up-front complexity, which is nothing but stuff to gloss over and to memorize.

I suprise myself with enjoying a small amount of accountancy when I'm alone, but I don't see any reason to spend my social leisure time with doing tax returns in parallel.

A reasonably fun sandbox experience. If you think AGRICOLA is too unforgiving and/or too "tight", then this is what you're looking for. It seems like there are always good actions to take and even if you get blocked from doing exactly what you wanted to do, chances are there are other actions available to which you can pivot and still generate a useful turn. The problem, to me, is that this significantly lowers the tension, and that's one of the things I find perfect about AGRICOLA.
I immediately regretted joining this game and immediately tuned out. I don't have much to say about it except that I never want to play it again.
20 minutes of upkeep/set-up/bookkeeping per 5 second decision. Even if the tedious stuff was automated there's not enough variability to give this replayability.
Dry and boring worker placement, one of the few games I almost fell asleep during.

I bought Caverna and played it once and I was so thoroughly turned off by the theme, the mechanics, and the aesthetics, that I went through the trouble of popping all the cardboard back into the punchboard and selling it as like new as possible. Playing Caverna is just a frustrating slog through an ugly game largely about animal husbandry. Never have I disliked a game so thoroughly after one play. From what I have read, I think I might just find that every game in Uwe Rosenberg's oeuvre is offputting to me.
Only played once. Too many pieces. Never again.

A reworking of Agricola into version 2.0. Less charm. Less theme. Less tension. Less of the stress that I liked. A long set up. But somehow it was still a decent game.

Update October 2014. Dropped from 7 to 5 to 3 to 2.
It really is just recycled Agricola. Not interested in looking at 100 buildings and maximizing grabbing and converting a thousand different types of resources. Feh. And extra -1 for recycling the same mechanics again and again.

I love the original Agricola for how harsh and unforgiving it is, and its tight gameplay. This feels much looser, and like the points salad style of eurogames which I don't enjoy. The game looks nice, it's easy to understand, learn, and grasp, but it sadly just annoys me. I've had the same reaction to all point salad games.
Not a 1 because with all those components stuffed into the box, it makes a sturdy doorstop.

Tried it once... and I will not waste my time explaining how much I dislike this game. Suffice to say that the theme was uninteresting, the gameplay was boring, and the playtime was 3 hours! Worst gaming experience I've ever had. Never playing this again.

Let's buy some sheep and plant some cabbage, using chips.
Let's not interact at all and just try to be really swift at picking up those +bonus tiles to snowball the ending after several hours of exhaustive play.
How did Catan got here? What happened?

At first, this game seemed like it was Agricola 2.0 as many claim it to be. You will enjoy it and have plenty of fun for a series of plays. However, overtime you will get bored of it and it will get extremely repetitive. It will get to the point where you simply just don't want to play anymore, or at least that's how I feel. I was planning on buying the game but my cousins beat me to it. At first I felt pretty bad because my Agricola game seemed impervious to this updated game, but not anymore.

First off, there is very little variance in the game. It's the same rooms every time and therefore you'll be going for the same strategy, every time. Sure, your strategy may change as plays are made and people end up taking your rooms and resources, but you still move onto other strategies which are also the same thing every game. The game is also way too easy, after all the games I've played, no one has gotten the beggar token. It's like there is no reason for it. Moves just aren't as meaningful as they are in Agricola, you're just never on the edge and while Agricola could of been a little more forgiving, this game is just intensely forgiving.

As for the expedition concept, it sounded great and was fun for a few, but eventually it became annoying and it's too powerful to avoid. This idea adds unnecessary length to the game as do all these additional actions we get when we compare this game to Agricola. The length of this game is just way too long, the more people, the worse it becomes. It's just so hard focusing in this game, makes me wanna do something else as I wait for everyone to take their turn. As for our player boards, I'm not sure why the developer would not allow them to nicely store resources on and to have them not be generic. Everyone has the same board for crying out loud, why?

In the end, this game is pretty bad and I no longer think it's better than Agricola. It was a direction that the developer shouldn't of went in with these farming board games, it just didn't work. I'm really not surprised why no expansions are being developed for it. The board also wasn't very colorful or appealing to look at, while that has no real importance, it's something to mention when the gameplay doesn't make up for it. Now instead of adding this game to my collection, I rather just purchase some expansions for Agricola.

As for right now there is only one way this game can be fixed and that's to add a major expansion which would add many more new rooms to the game where we can put in a bag, mix up for each game, and draw them out on the table so things are different each time, giving us different strategies to work with, which would greatly increase replayability in the game.

So wait a minute, wait a minute here. Wait a minute.

You're telling me the reason why Caverna is better than Agricola is because ALL the stuff is available for ALL players to grab, and therefore once I solve the puzzle it's a matter of who gets the perfect route the fastest?

Yeah, no thanks.
A Solitaire Snoozefest. No meaningful interaction and poor integration of theme. I never felt like a dwarf, just a mediocre mathematician.
Far too fiddly for the limited excitement it generates

While the mechanics are nice, there is just not enough pressure as in Agricola and the replayability is a lot lower, too. In addition, you do too much per action, diminishing the importance of certain actions.
utterly typical...

Not my cuppa tea. But with a different skin, I think it has great potential. I am just not into a game where the theme is Dwarven Farmers. I would rather spend my time reading a book or playing just about any other game apart from BLUFF.
Farming and sheeps...deja vu. Agricola is a better game.
Uwe's idea of fun is nothing like mine. I've yet to play a game of his that I've enjoyed.

While I was very enthusiastic about Caverna, watched many wideos and played it twice. However, for our group playing Caverna always seemed like a chore, but without the gratification when you are done with it.
It's good, but I think the puzzle lacks tension. As much as I like playing with little wooden animals, I don't need a rules system to do that neccesarily.

Friendly worker placement game. In Agricola, you need the spot someone else takes. In this game, there still a spot you can take, but just less efficient than the spot you really want. Agricola is the better game.
I will never play this game again. It took way too long time to play and the game wasn't interesting enough.
Another game of planting vegetables.......zzzzz........

3/5

great game, but having content for 7 players is overkill and hurts due to the cost of the game. the setup is a killer. the gameplay is awesome. a sandbox with high replayability.

Just play Agricola instead. Every game feels the same because there is no card drafting and every building is available each time. The addition of the wild resource ruby and action spaces which combine multiple actions together eliminates the action drafting tension that makes Agricola so fun.

I'm really surprised this scores as high as it does.

First let me preface by saying I Love both Agricola and Feast for Odin. Even though this game has less choice, and less things going on than FFO.....it does not feel like it. Somehow this middlestep between agricola and FFO just feels like trying to cram as much extra shit as they could into the Agricola framework. Agricola works becasue of the limited options, and tight spaces to get those options accomplished in. This game somehow trys to get you to accomplish even more things, within the same amount of turns(less turns in a 2 player game i believe) as Agricola.

The double sided tiles, combined with all the different animals, and resources, this covers our entire table for a 2 player game. It's a slog to put out the rocks, wood, ore, rubies, animals every turn on the action spaces.


Really disappointed based on the high ratings it gets. I'd never want to play this over Feast for Odin, or Agricola. Both of those games either do less things, much better in Agricolas case, or more things, much better, in Odin's case.

Played on BGA and it was not a fun experience to play as a newbie with another newbie who had analysis paralysis with each turn in a real-time game... it took us 3.5 hours to finish 1 game. With that aside, I didn't really feel that the mechanisms were aligning with the theme well enough, so learning and choosing things was not an intuitive or satisfying process.
One of my least favorite big euros. It has the frontloaded tech tree (buildings) that I can't stand, the lack of tightness does not help, and it is overly long for my taste.

Overly-long and overly-wrought engine builder, clearly built from Agricola (which I never thought was as good, as elegant or as fun as Caylus or the much ignored Cuba, anyway). I know this sort of thing is loved by gamers, but honestly, I can think of scores of games I'd rather play for 2-3 hours rather than this one.
Yawn.

So inferior to Agricola.
Why does this exist?
Not bad, but I would never pick this over Agricola. There's less tension, and Caverna's buildings aren't as interesting as the Agricola's profession deck.

Maybe would have been more enjoyable had I played it when it came out but in 2021 a generic worker placement game just doesn't cut it. Would much rather play Bora Bora or Tzolkein or Castles of Burgundy
more typical Uwe garbage

1-7jug
Comprado 06/12/2015
en Mathom
Precio:60€
Inserto hecho.

Fixes the restrictive nature of acrigola by giving you tons of choice sadly all meaningless and the theme apart from collecting animals is trash. Point soup with horrific UI half the players will be reading upside down terrible.
A lower version of agricola
ITs just too complicated to get people to play. Loong waiting time between turns. Guess its a cool game but we simply cant sit for that long. And we play Dungeons and dragons

I prefer both Agricola and especially A Feast for Odin. I find this one very boring. Turns aren't very interesting, it's a less punishing rip-off of Agricola, and adventuring gets you... sheep and cows? Really? The solo mode is particularly static and many of the buildings, while probably useful in some situations, aren't very interesting.
It's like Agricola, only twice the pieces and stuff to learn.

Great game! I like the theme of A Feast for Odin better and Brew Crafter's is also similar enough worker placement wise. I'd happily play it again (at no more than 4 players) but I didn't think I NEED it anymore.

Worker placement games are hit or miss for me. This was a miss. Not enough flexibility in jobs for your workers. Bonus points are also incredibly swingy; if you miss out on the one you need, you're pretty much out of the game.
Quite a bit more forgiving than Agricola, with a less-variable setup, makes me prefer the progenitor, but I’d still play this if asked.
Was not impressed. Hope to never see again.

It was fine, but not nearly as good as east of Odin. I felt a little frustrated because I never had quite enough workers to do whatever I wanted to do, which means that the game really comes down to scrambling for workers early in which case why not just give people more workers
The worst of Uwe in my mind. Other players choices rarely impact me, might as well be playing solitaire. Don't feel the length of the game is justified by the game play. Would rather play Agricola.

incidental interaction

Fixes everything I don't like about Agricola, EXCEPT FOR THE INFINITE COMBO involving The Spare Part Storage, The Trader, and The Seam

I still feel Uwe's designs are overly complex.
No interest

At first I thought Caverna was better than Agricola, but now I'm not sure. Agricola suffers from luck of the draw, while Caverna suffers from too complex actions that take too long to execute. I do like how all buildings are available from the start, as it lets all players compete for strong buildings and combos but prepare for some AP if you're a new player.

Le Havre is still the best of the three though.

7 players is madness. Never play with more than 4.
Complicated

I was hugely disappointed with this, after loving Agricola so, so much. It's hard not to compare Caverna to Agricola since the mechanisms are identical but this didn't have any of the tightness and struggle that I love in Agricola. It felt loose and aimless with too much information to absorb on the room tiles. It just didn't come close to Agricola as an experience for me or for my group. We missed the taut, economical, streamlined flow of Agricola.

Also, I'm completely baffled as to why this box includes enough pieces and boards for seven players! Who on earth is going to use this? It's a long game anyway at 2p but at 7 players? I'd have thought that it's exceedingly rare that anyone would want to put themselves through that so why not have made Caverna 4-player and released an expansion for more players, just like they did with Agricola? As such, Caverna has an increased cost and shelf footprint which is totally unnecessary.

This is the most repetitive game I've seen in a while. No variability. On your second game you're already repeating the same patterns because the setup is static. Boring and outdated. Despite its own flaws Agricola is a better game.

Better than Agricola, but still not a very engaging game. The theme is lackluster and the art is sub-par.
It has the same problem as its predecessor with too many bits and too many tiles with too many tiny words. It's just not a pleasurable experience teaching or playing the game. It's an impressive amount of cardboard and plastic, but it would be even more impressive if it had been whittled down into a better game.

Played 6-player game. Downtime is horrible, game is composed out of microrules and components are flying around in high numbers.

I tried to have fun, but I didn't.
Agricola, but with all the good bits removed and the bad bits made bigger.
Vendere

Played, enjoyed, but even though it plays more cleanly than Agricola, and gives you more interesting options with less screwing around and more flexibility, I don't think it's better.

Firstly, I am extremely suspicious of balance. Mining, looting, and a few of the mining boosters seem extremely strong. I've never seen anyone win who wasn't heavily into mining and got one or more of the three extremely strong rooms (food with donkeys in mines, extra ore for mines, points for ore). Many of the other rooms related to agriculture and husbandry are obviously laughably weak. Also, there seems to be a significant first turn first player advantage.

Secondly, the huge amount of up-front complexity, along with completely open and symmetric information is obviously problematic. With little inherent variability, this will be susceptible to optimal strategies and severe AP. I see the problems he was trying to solve, but this "solution" just introduces a different set of severe issues.

Also, the 7p support is ludicrous and has jacked up the retail for no good reason. Even 5p is probably a little too thin. 6 or 7p would be insane.

So I dunno. We were basically done with Agricola, and Caverna is kind of fun because it gets the system back to the table again with some neat new features. But I expect it to have a short shelf life.

Last thing, while Caverna is pretty playable for Agricola vets, for anyone who hasn't played Agricola, Caverna can be completely overwhelming. Newbies are going to have to plow through several or many games of frustration to catch up.
dent in lower right lid

Sandbox-feeling and fantasy themed combined with beautiful components and engaging strategy. Fun to play casually ("look at my cute farm!") and competitively.

Includes the Forgotten Folk expansion w/ Halfling promo and Broken Token organizer. I think the Forgotten Folk expansion really helps by mixing up the otherwise static building pool, and the organizer makes it much easier to set up the game.
I was disappointed with this game.

This version of Agricola is a bit more open allowing for more specialization and probably even pushes you that direction. Food doesn't feel quite as tight despite having to feed quite often in the game and the 7 unknown harvest/feeding chits can be rather frustrating when they come up in the wrong order for you...;-)

Instead of cards being used to provide variation, the rooms provide unique actions and abilities of which most there are only one of each except for the base dwelling. Adventuring is an interesting addition to the game as well which allows a person to go off and pillage stuff which is often better as you improve your weaponry. Frankly, this is the part of the game that really gets me interested in playing as it is really unique from the other "Agricolas".

It does not feel nearly as vicious as the original, but I find it quite interesting and enjoyable. I don't believe I would still ever play with more than 5...and possibly not more than 4 just to avoid downtime.

Four player makes for a much tighter game than three player thus far in my brief experience. Imitation was used far more often in the four player game.

Very enjoyable game. The first game felt much more stressful than subsequent plays because I had a better idea of actions needed to feed my dwarfs. Also played at 4 the first game with all of us as first plays which probably made it a bit harder. Would like to play this with 3 or 4 again at some point but most of my gaming is done at 2 which this game still shines at.

Quotes from me from my first play - “I like this 50% better than Agricola” (which I rate a 3).

Even “liking it 20% better” for winning, it’s still a 5.
Keep

Una versión de Agrícola que, por una parte, le quita algo de agobio al juego (lo cual no está mal) pero que tiene algunos puntos que para mí flojean respecto a su hermano mayor: como que todas las habitaciones están disponibles desde el principio o las "expediciones" de los enanos, que son un pegote espectacular.

Pero lo que menos me gusta es que no hay restricciones en la puntuación. Puedes hacer puntos con lo que quieras, como si quieres centrarte en tener 20 jabalíes.
Really mean worker placement game. Seems to have swapped out the cards for the open building play similar to Glass Road. Easier resource conversion than the prior game.

iOS version.

I was a beta tester for this game.
Had ik geweten dat dit zoveel op Agricola zou lijken, had ik m waarschijnlijk niet gespeeld. Alles levert puntjes of punten op, ontzettend veel keuzes en motortjes te maken, het wordt wat breien.
sale

In the worker placement game Caverna the focus of Agricola on agriculture is mixed with a focus on forging weapons to go on expeditions and get loot. Personally, I don't like that new part at all. The getting loot mechanism doesn't attract me and I don't like the generic dwarf theme.
I am not really a fan on Acricola either, but I prefer it to Caverna because of the sole focus on agriculture and the feed your people theme.
Thema nicht so meins
So many pieces

I find this more enjoyable than Agricola in some ways. In Caverna, you escape subsistence farming and I start to feel like I've really built something by the end of the game. This is especially true for the expeditions, which can be really lucrative.

I don't love the large number of buildings. I find that number of choices to be unpleasant in almost all of Uwe's games. But it does bring the Agricola format into line with his more recent offerings.

See my thoughts about other Uwe Rosenberg games in my Uwe Rosenberg Games I've Played geeklist.
Agricola but with better scoring rules and waaaaay worse replayability

A significantly worse version of Agricola (it's predecessor game!)

- More bloated than Agricola - you start with too many buildings that are all out at once. Usability issues, as these buildings can't easily be seen from across the table - compared to having cards in hand in Agricola.

- Despite the many buildings, there is no variety between games - you could try the same strategy every game. This is the biggest downgrade from Agricola, where you have to be creative each time with which cards you drew - and provides limitless replayability.

- Less tense than Agricola - the tension is what makes the game good!

- Subjective but - the theme is better in Agricola than Caverna too

Like the other uwe rosenberg games I've played (Nusfjord, cave vs cave), this feels characteristically Uwe. This one has more going on than the other two titles. I had no problem handling the complexity, although two newer players were overwhelmed. Uwe's games aren't particularly exciting or rewarding to me, maybe I'm just spoiled by more hybrid WP games like Gaia project, on mars, keyflower, the gallerist, and others that have more going on. The mechanics are classic and competitive, but the games feel a bit aged even compared to much older games like caylus or many classic knizias. I think straight worker placement just isn't really for me, even if we'll executed.

Agricola the Family Game: The Game, not just because there is no hidden information, but also because it's much more forgiving. Resources can be converted to food anytime, it is easier to gain a Dwarf and they're worth less, penalties only for missing animals and tiles and no limit to scoring each category etc. Worked much better in practice than in theory, since I felt like I was watching the board and players instead of getting distracted by managing my hand. A slight bit of randomness in the timing of harvests in addition to the order of the action spaces so one can't script completely. Feels satisfying to watch your farm develop.

My obvious Caverna and Agricola comparison:

Caverna is for boardgamers who play a game once or twice and move on to the next game.
I played it 4 times, did the same strategy which seemed very strong and won every time. Then I sold the game.

Agricola is for boardgamers who like to explore all the intricacies and possibilities the game has to offer. Impossible to master.

For me this was meh. I just don't feel like I'm doing much. Feeding workers is still one of the most annoying mechanics in all of gaming. Too much of the game was fiddlying with that and trying to get more workers. Oh that and constantly having to add resources to worker spots. There is a reason most games only do this with 1 or 2 spots, not 8. Very annoying. I did like how fast the 2 player game works. And it is very smooth for the most part. I would play it if a group asked, but I would never request to play it. Which is how I feel about a lot of classic euro games.

Long setup and mostly boring

A good game that partially improved on Agricola by lifting the VP restrictions, which in theory allows for more tailored playstyles, for example getting massive vps from stones. Unfortunately, by doing away with the cards it made the possible combos weaker and less interesting. Also, the menu-style "adventuring" is so dry and unthematic that it doesn't feel right.

The threat of starvation in Agricola is a source of stress for us, and the game ends right when we finally get the puzzle solved so we never really get to see our engine running smoothly, which robs us of a little satisfaction. I'd like to try Caverna before buying to see if the lack of card variety is a dealbreaker despite the removal of the starvation threat. Rahdo thinks Glass Road is better than this, and it plays faster, so we're going to give that a shot first.

UPDATE AFTER FIRST PLAY: OMG, so much more relaxing and enjoyable than Agricola. It's so much more streamlined and straightforward. I feel like I could actually teach this to people and that they'd enjoy playing. This game is just plain fun. Thank you Uwe Rosenberg.

UPDATE AFTER 2nd PLAY: I successfully taught this to 6 new gamers, ages from 11 to 45. Everybody had fun. This would not have happened with Agricola (on their first play).

UPDATE AFTER 5th PLAY: I can see the validity of the criticisms regarding the sameness of every game. I'm not to the point where it bugs me yet, but I can already appreciate what Agricola did with the cards and variability between games more as time goes on.

UPDATE AFTER MORE PLAYS: We've dabbled with a print-and-play version of the Forgotten Folk expansion and I kind of like the directionality and asymmetry this brings to the game. My tastes are changing lately and there's something about Uwe's designs that is causing me to lose some interest. Several of his games have endgame scoring criteria that encourage all players to end up with very similar results. This is ultimately less interesting to me than divergent play with very different results, though perhaps that is hardest to design for and balance. At the end of the game, for the most part, all players will have similar looking farms / homesteads. It would be more interesting for me if I could explore a plants-only or animals-only or mining-only strategy and still remain competitive. Harmonies is one example where players are building different ecosystems to satisfy different animals. When I look around the table at the end of the game, each player's tableau tells a little story. Fantasy Realms is another one that has players follow completely different paths, where their ending hand tells a story, and they usually remain competitive.

UPDATE AFTER A WHILE:
My tastes have changed. Component-bloat, fiddly setup, feeding your people, the full menu of buildings overwhelming new players, needing to apply variants to try to turn the game into what I wish it was, all add up to me not wanting to get this game out again. Setting it up is a chore. The fiddlyness of updating the board every round. That the game guides all players to a similar end result for scoring rather than allowing creativity and divergent gameplay. Putting it up for sale / trade. It had a good run.

Something about Caverna just doesn't totally do it for me. It's hard to put my finger on, maybe it was the established meta of the group I played it with, combined with the multiplayer solitare, but it just wasn't interesting enough to want to dive into. Still think it's a decent game, and I see why people like it.

Thinking back to my plays of this, it's interesting to think of why I bounced off it a bit. It was one of my first hobby games, and the hype at the time. I was coming from Terra Mystica: the first serious game I ever bought. I hadn't heard the term "multiplayer solitare" before, and in retrospect, I think this was where I discovered that I disliked it. The players I played with were experienced, and all opened with the same moves. This immediately coloured my experience, as there was nothing I could do about it, nor did it effect my decisions, besides showing me that my plan was clearly worse. Caverna definitely played an important part in showing me what I liked, and to not always believe the hype.

Overall there's still some fun here, typical Euro stuff: choose a direction in your strategy and optimize as well as you can for it. There's enough variability that if someone really liked it I would play it with them and try out something new. Just not my thing.

To misquote one of the great philosophers of our time: "Well, I would go with Concordia... but I'd be thinking of Agricola."

The dwarf theming instantly disappears in the background, but surprisingly the farming aspect disappears as well - I just don't feel like I'm running a farm, because of the mechanical restictions of the system - the rules around dogs feel especially mechanical. It's evident that the whole thing is very cleverly designed and the math works, and I even suspect that there is a chance for more player interaction than you'd think at first. But I probably expected it to feel a bit more like a wide open farming simulator sandbox, and it really doesn't - it feels like a mid-weight euro board game (which it is) where you have a lot of options, yes, but if you want to stay competitive you better find the optimal ones. I also just don't love the furnishing tiles; I wish they would unlock cooler, weirder abilities than what they provide. There's a ton of them, but in scope, they are all very similar.

This game could really use a revised edition. While Rosenberg’s design is solid, it’s held back by clunky graphic design, the lack of an organizer, and an unattractive cover. The board looks dull, with a confusing mix of icons and text. You have to place a card off to the side to track something instead of it being integrated into the board. The food trades are the only aid printed on the player board, while other aids are a mix of cards and cardboard. Adding variants to randomize the starting tiles, similar to Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small, would be a nice improvement for a second edition. It really needs an organizer, a combined player aid, a tile reference for all players, and a way to store tiles in place on the boards.

It's not a game I clamour to play every night but when I do I really enjoy it. Solid game. Reiterates Agricola but does away with the cards. That is both an upside (less reading, more playing) as a downside (no variety in setup, risk of favorite strategy lock-in). Also a little friendlier and scoring is easier.

Components are superb, solo play is good as well and there are much, much more choices at any time as in Agricola which is nice if you felt constricted for choice in that game. Another plus is the variety from player count to player count: each player count has it's own set of starting actions available, so the game will differ with each player count.

In short: a huge action space and variability by player count does lessen the pre-set nature of it all but it is still there (favorite lock-in strategies). So with repeated plays with the same group this game might become stale earlier as Agricola.

That being said, an expansion is on the way which probably adds a lot of modular expansions and at least one variable setup (don't know if it does but would be surprised if it would not).

Which game is better? Tough to say. Not burned out on the strategy of Caverna by a long shot, so for now I drift towards it a little more as towards Agricola. In the long run, I see Agricola taking back its spot as it is more variable. But the expansion changes all that and I'm fairly sure I won't hit saturation level with Caverna before that, so for the moment it is Caverna.

For new players this is definitely a friendlier game to pick up, but they need to be experienced gamers as the action space is pretty large. All the playing pieces do really give you a sense of tableau-building, having your nice little farm/cave. My kids loved that feeling, even though the actual game went way over their head. As such, it is a lot of work for dad so not something I'm really eager to break out with them again. Then again, if they request it, how can I say no?

Colocación de trabajadores ambientado en un clan de enanos que decide dedicarse a mejorar sus cuevas y dominios exteriores. Inevitable compararlo con Agricola.

La premisa del juego es similar a su primo mayor: gestionas una familia de enanos que tiene acceso tanto a su caverna para obtener recursos de la minería así como a sus dominios exteriores de alrededor. Es el mismo sistema de juego que Agricola: un jugador elige una acción, la ejecuta y el siguiente elige cualquier otra y la ejecuta, revelándose más acciones conforme el juego avanza.

Uwe Rosemberg ha diseñado un gran juego tras años de feedback de los jugadores de Agricola. Añade nuevas mecánicas que parecen hacer el juego menos exigente con la alimentación de la familia y expanden las formas de ganar de su predecesor. Estas mecánicas son:

- La ausencia de cartas. La viarabilidad y los poderes especiales de oficios y adquisiciones menores se ven sustituidas por las habitaciones, que están al alcance de todos.

- Aventuras. Una mecánica que emplea la acción de forjar gracias a un nuevo recurso llamado mineral. Permite obtener mejores recursos conforme mejore la calidad del armamento.

- Reduce la importancia de la familia. Ahora es más sencillo alimentarla (no hace falta convertir el trigo en pan o cocinar los animales) y sus miembros otorgan menos PV´s que en Agricola (1 PV en vez de 3 PV´s).

- Al igual que en Ora et Labora, la situación de las habitaciones en el tablero personal, cobra su importancia.

- Hay un recurso que puede usarse como comodín (rubíes).

Si buscas un final más abierto, un juego más permisivo con los errores y con un sentido más claro de "construir algo", decántate por Caverna. Si buscas un juego más estricto que recomepense al más habilidoso, Agricola.

PROS: Menos punitivo. De entrada, menos exigente para novatos.

CONS: Partidas más largas. Mesa extremadamente grande para jugarlo a gusto. Montarlo (y desmontarlo) necesita más tiempo del que piensas.
My family gateway into board gaming world, will never sell this, good worker placement, prefer this with house rules (room drafting) to Agricola
BGA
still like Agricola a tad more due to its tightness. but Caverna is pretty darn good.
Love this game!!!
Fun game but prefer Agricola. Would always pick Agricola first
Bought at Millenium 1/15/19 used for $40.
river exp +inne dodatki
preliminary rating after first play.

Designed by Uwe Rosenberg. Best straight worker placement game I've played! Reimplements and improves Agricola. Compared to it, Caverna is a bit looser, less punishing. The Forgotten Folk expansion is highly regarded and adds asymmetric factions.

Far better variation of Agricola.
And in comparison to Agricola - it has great replayability

With so many little tiles, at a glance Caverna seems really daunting and complicated, but it ain't too bad once you get it all set up. Decision-making is pretty straightforward, but there are a lot of options.
ESSAYER AVEC EXTENSION
3D Insert

For me Caverna is the better Agricola, mainly due to the fact that you are free to specialize and don't need to balance everything on point. Moreover I prefer the open offer of many caverns (or buildings) over all the cards in Agricola. Both games are definitively worth trying!
Sleeved & Inserted

Why did I wait so long to play this? I like Agricola (and the 2P version), and this is quite similar. Farming AND cave dwelling! These types of games definitely take practice to get used to, the "pain" of working so hard all game to build something, and then have it end right when you were satisfied But that grid keeps calling me back, to try to get better and better at it. (I'd be interested in trying the 2P version of this too!)

One of my top favorite games and my family enjoys it too. Not to cut throat when playing a friendly game and you can go in a bunch of different building directions. Of all my plays so far I haven't done the same strategy twice as I like to try different things. My daughter is an adventurer and my wife is a livestock/farmer every game. We enjoy all the pieces, I've bought storage boxes to minimize setup/clean up of the game.
Solo
This clicked more with me than its older sister, Agricola.
I love this game. Even worked at 7 players (though very long and was my learning game, so I needed the time). I would play this a lot more if it wasn't too heavy for my group.
Another of Rosenberg CLASSICS!!!
Great game play that creates a thematic experience. It’s worth the long set up to see the world that you can create
In-game free
Base game: 10/10, BGA: 4/10
It just keeps bringing me back by wanting to try a different strat to beat my previous high score. Unexpectedly addicting.
Really great game. My personal favorite of the Uwe Rosenburgs. Though I really like A Feast for Odin, this one is easier to setup and teach.
Walls Storage
If only the game was a looker! Really fun worker placement, you want to accomplish so much then you get blocked on a spot or furnishing taken then you have to pivot.

This game just slightly edged out Agricola for me but ultimately, despite similar mechanisms, the strategy is almost polar opposites. You get more choices in how you want to play and you can experiment with different specializations. Definitely room in my collection for both Agricola AND Caverna.

My wife and I got this to the table for the first time. We played it 5 times now in the first week. We've played Agricola maybe a dozen times and love it (I rated it a 10 also). This game is either new and shiny, or just more fun for us to explore different possibilities.
Mega Spiel! Macht eigentlich alles richtig!
